document.masterDocTitle: A review of the genus Speocarcinus Stimpson, 1859 (Crustacea: Brachyura: Xanthidae), with a key to its species and the description of one new species

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 5. A–F, Male thoracic sternum (abdomen not represented). A,
Speocarcinus amazonicus Brandão, Tavares
& Coelho- Filho, 2010, holotype cl 8 mm, cw 11 mm (MZUSP 23654). B,
Speocarcinus carolinensis Stimpson, 1859
, cl 10 mm, cw 14 mm (USNM 180101). C,
Speocarcinus dentatus
n. sp .
, holotype cl 11.5 mm, cw 22.5 mm (MZUSP 12615). D,
Speocarcinus lobatus Guinot, 1969
, cl 5 mm, cw 10 mm (USNM 187191). E,
Speocarcinus meloi D’Incao & Silva, 1991
, holotype cl 12 mm, cw 15.6 mm (MZUSP 9577). St. 4–7, thoracic sternites 4 to 7. Scale bars: A–E, 2 mm.

FIGURE 6. A–F, Abdominal segments 1–5, ventro-posterior view. A,
Speocarcinus amazonicus Brandão, Tavares
& Coelho- Filho, 2010, holotype male cl 8 mm, cw 11 mm (MZUSP 23654). B,
Speocarcinus carolinensis Stimpson, 1859
, male cl 10 mm, cw 14 mm (USNM 180101). C,
Speocarcinus dentatus
n. sp .
, male holotype cl 11.5 mm, cw 22.5 mm (MZUSP 12615). D,
Speocarcinus lobatus Guinot, 1969
, male cl 5 mm, cw 10 mm (USNM 187191). E,
Speocarcinus meloi D’Incao & Silva, 1991
, holotype male cl 12 mm, cw 15.6 mm (MZUSP 9577). F,
Speocarcinus spinicarpus Guinot, 1969
, male cl 7 mm, cw 14 mm (USNM 127056). Note in C–D the abdominal segment 2 partially intercalated between edges of the abdominal segments 3–5. a2, abdominal segment 2; a3–5 abdominal segments 3 to 5 fused. St. 6–8, thoracic sternites 6 to 8. Scale bars: A–F, 2 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks. Large and small individuals of
S. carolinensis
look very different from each other. In large individuals the carapace anterolateral teeth are remarkably stronger and much more pronounced than in smaller ones, in which the last anterolateral tooth may even be no more than a prominent granule (
Fig. 1 A, B
). Small and medium size individuals of
S. carolinensis
and
S. lobatus
are very similar in respect to the carapace anterolateral teeth ( Figs.

1 B; 2 C. See also
Felder & Rabalais, 1986
).
Speocarcinus carolinensis
, however, can be separated from
S. lobatus
by (i) the branchiostegal region of the carapace with dispersed distinct granules, but no transversal row of granules (
Fig. 3 B
) (one distinct transversal row of granules in
S. lobatus
,
Fig. 3 D
); (ii) the ocular peduncle is smooth (
Fig. 4 A
) (ocular peduncle distinctly granular in
S. lobatus
); (iii) male abdominal segment 2 free, not intercalated between edges of abdominal segments 3–5 (
Fig. 6 B
) (male abdominal segment 2 partially intercalated between edges of abdominal segments 3–5 in
S. lobatus
, fig. 6 D).

Small male and female individuals of
S. carolinensis
also closely resemble
S. monotuberculatus
, from which they can be separated by the absence of a dorsal median tubercle on abdominal segment 2 , whereas in
S. monotuberculatus
the male and female abdominal segment 2 has one dorsal median tubercle (
Felder & Rabalais 1986
).
Distribution. North Carolina (south of Cape Hatteras) to the Gulf of Mexico and the West Indies, between 15 and 43 m deep.
